newsitem.title: INDIA: India stocks end with small losses in dull trade.
newsitem.headline: India stocks end with small losses in dull trade.

text.p: ** (1230 GMT) - Stocks at Indian bourses finish lower
after lack of follow-up buying wipes out early rally
** Market's roller-coaster ride attributed to heavy
** Gujarat Ambuja Cement reports 20 pct rise in first half
net profit to 489.8 million rupees, share loses 2.72 pct
** Delhi index falls 0.96 pct to 732.58, Calcutta sheds
0.98 pct to 437.02 and Madras 0.26 pct to 3,254.48
** National bourse index up 4.20 pts, or 0.43 pct to 962.50
Indian shares closed slightly lower on Wednesday in a session dominated by speculative action, dealers said.
Traders said the slide near the session's close took them by surprise, but attributed no single major factor to the fall.
"There was no reason for the market to have dropped as it did today," said chief dealer Sanjeev Choithani at brokers Pashupati Advani. "This is a big speculative game going on."
The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) 30-share index fell 71.95 points from the day's high of 3,426.67 to end at 3,354.72 -- a net loss of 22.91 points or 0.68 percent over Tuesday's close.
"It's very difficult to understand the market trend. There's hardly any institutional activity," said a dealer at a local brokerage.
Positive remarks by Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda helped rally share prices in morning trade.
The Economic Times newspaper said on Wednesday that Deve Gowda had hinted the 1997 budget, due at the end of February, would include a package of measures to boost investor sentiment.
"When we present the budget, there will be more indications for investors to get a further favourable investment message," the paper quoted Gowda as telling a news conference.
